Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Revealing the Role of Less-Mobile Porosity in Hyporheic Denitrification and Greenhouse Gas Production?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Streams and rivers have a remarkable cleansing function for natural and human generated contaminants, as microbes living in the streambed can transform these contaminants into less harmful compounds. Excess nitrogen in our terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems is now considered one of the greatest global-scale threats to humanity by degrading water quality and producing a powerful greenhouse gas. This research couples the cleansing function of rivers to this global excess nitrogen issue. Streambed bacteria can break down the reactive nitrogen compounds, primarily releasing non-reactive nitrogen gas that returns harmlessly to the atmosphere. However, a fraction is released as the strong greenhouse gas nitrous-oxide (N2O). Compelling data indicates pockets of longer-term water storage in streambeds, or microzones, create the low-oxygen conditions needed to both break-down dissolved nitrogen and form N2O. New remote sensing techniques of streambed microzones will allow us to better resolve the how nitrogen is attenuated and transformed through river transport, improving evaluations of watershed nutrient mitigation and helping better predict future climate change. Further, this research will dovetail with STEM education via community level partnerships with established outreach institutions. Outreach partners (Impression 5 Science Center and MSUSiFest) specialize in developing, executing and evaluating STEM exhibits and activities for children ages 4-12 and community "life-learners", both of which are key STEM demographics. Project PIs will connect with UConn undergraduate design teams and outreach partners to develop novel groundwater and streambed flow model exhibits and inquiry-based demonstrations designed to harness society's increasing fascination with real-time sensing and interaction. Outreach partners will use these products to illustrate principles of groundwater flow, contaminant transport, and greenhouse gas production, reaching 150,000+ students and community members each year.

This project will link and quantify transient storage via dual-domain mass transport principles with the biogeochemical functions of stream sediments to reveal new insights on hyporheic denitrification and stream N2O production. This work is timely because recent global assessments reveal that rivers are major N2O producers, but the mechanism and spatial distribution of production remain unknown. Contrary to existing biogeochemical models for stream sediments, it is hypothesized that nitrate reduction to N2O occurs predominantly within streambed sediments that are oxic in a bulk sense but have local, anoxic less-mobile pore spaces. Largely overlooked in past work, these anoxic microsites must be mechanistically understood in order to upscale freshwater nitrogen dynamics from point, to reach, to basin scales. New observation methods and process-based models are needed to account for the role of anoxic microsites in fluid exchange and nitrogen biogeochemistry. Recently, project team members developed electrical geophysical methods for inference of less-mobile parameters, as the electric field can directly sense spatially variable solute dynamics in less-mobile porosity. Other team members have focused on developing labeled 15N tracer methods to reveal residence time controls on denitrification. These techniques will be combined to unlock the presence and function of anoxic microsites. The workplan comprises controlled laboratory experiments, numerical modeling, and field experiments at an established research site in the Ipswich Watershed, MA, USA. Our work will directly connect new process-based understanding to existing river network nitrate models, extending and capitalizing on previous NSF LINXII research. Specifically, the intrinsic properties of less-mobile pore space will be characterized, the existence of anoxic microsites and denitrification occurring in anaerobic microsites will be quantified, and multi-scale patterns of river nitrogen biogeochemistry will be enhanced. Overall, this work will transform the current understanding of hyporheic microsite processes, providing new mechanistic models of the role of hyporheic zones on watershed solute transport, nitrogen cycling and greenhouse gas production. The proposed research will address big questions about some very small places in our watersheds by quantifying hydrodynamic exchange with previously uncharacterized less-mobile hyporheic pore space.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many recent studies revealed clues that pointed toward a paradox occurring in stream ecosystems: that there may be small zones within saturated stream sediments whose properties and chemical functions vastly differ from the majority of the surrounding stream sediment. This project sought to address this paradox directly and deemed these small anomalous zones “microzones.” The project used a suite of interdisciplinary experimental, observational, and modelling studies to reveal the presence and properties of these microzones in streams. Outcomes from this project show that these microzones are likely ubiquitous in stream sediments but evaded prior discovery because they are very difficult to locate and sample due to their small size using only traditional methods. This project also discovered that these microzones are not just in streams, but are also found in some lake sediments. Overall, these microzones are exciting because they might be a key to understanding a range of other confounding findings in stream research, such as offering answers to why streams can remove more pollutants or produce more greenhouse gases than previously expected.

Transferable discoveries about microzone formation and function were generated via the integration of theory and methods from hydrology, geophysics, microbial biology, biogeochemistry in each of the project studies. These transferable discoveries will guide many future projects and disciplines working in watershed processes and management. The intellectual merit and key transferable findings about microzones are: 1. Microzones often occur in locations where there is little to no oxygen in shallow freshwater sediments, which can trigger a variety of larger scale outcomes for solutes, nutrients, contaminants, and organisms. 2. To measure and model microzone formation and chemical function there must be an accounting of the interacting physical and biological processes to see what conditions promote, suppress, or sustain microzones within a stream ecosystem. Microzones can theoretically arise from just hydraulics or biologically-mediated controls, but this project showed that natural microzones are created by the interplay between fundamental physical and biological processes occurring in stream and lake sediments. 3. Given this biophysical interplay and the variability of hydraulic and water chemistry conditions in aquatic ecosystems, microzones will form under many conditions and will be dynamic through space and time. 4. Microbial biology, often overlooked in stream sediment studies, plays a highly important role in microzone processes, especially by creating biomass that clogs sediment pores and prevents microzones from forming or functioning in a stream ecosystem. 5. Land use and stream disturbances that alter stream properties will control the formation and function of microzones. For example, urbanization of a watershed often shifts the flow regime in the channel, the properties of the sediment size and sorting, and the abundance of nutrients in the water. Each of these shifts will impact stream microzone formation and function. 6. Data produced during this project was archived and made accessible via publically available databases (CUAHSI Hydroshare).

This project also facilitated multiple broader scholarly and societal impacts. It partially supported the training of three graduate students and five undergraduate students. Each of these students has gone on to pursue an advanced degree (e.g., becoming a top recruit for graduate programs or a NSF GRFP fellow) or secure employment positions of their choice (e.g., becoming a private sector consultant or a state geologist). Six of the eight students identify as members of historically underrepresented groups in STEM, and their continued success to date is helping to broaden participation in STEM.

The microzone research topic, along with more general watershed processes and functions, were presented to a large number of scholarly and general public audiences each year of the project, both domestically and internationally. In total, over 25 scholarly presentations were made at conferences and academic institutions. The project team members generated 7 peer-reviewed papers within the direct scope of the project, and the team facilitated completion of another 13 closely related peer-reviewed papers. For general public audience groups, multiple approaches were taken to create scalable and transferable education and outreach presentations and exhibits. For example, project personnel advised and help create a new ~4,000 square foot Water Room Exhibit at a community-serving STEM center in Lansing, Michigan, which receives as many as 1 million visitors annually. This project also helped fund efforts to develop two new groundwater interactive education exhibits that were tested, refined, and assessed at multiple STEM outreach events across Michigan. These exhibits continue to be used at new venues and are being adopted by other outreach groups within and outside of Michigan.
